snippet: Despite a host of programs, the New York Police Department struggles to effectively respond to non-English speakers who are in need of translators.
abstract: New York City has nearly 2 million residents who do not speak English, and many of them report that in frantic, often frightening minutes just after a crime occurred, their pleas for assistance in their native language were ignored by police officers; victim advocates say such encounters show that for all its efforts and intentions, Police Dept is falling short of its goals, and of a 2008 mayoral order requiring that non-English speakers be given meaningful access to police services in city’s most frequently spoken languages.

byline.contributor: Michael Schwirtz contributed reporting. Susan C. Beachy contributed research.

lead_paragraph: Despite a host of programs, the New York Police Department struggles to effectively respond to non-English speakers who are in need of translators.

headline.main: Language Barrier Continues to Thwart Victims of Crimes
